docs.lead_paragraph: Of the many goals of the managed care revolution, few had as much resonance as the push to get people out of the nation's emergency rooms. With health maintenance organizations, everyone was supposed to have a primary care doctor who would manage routine aches and pains. Preventive care would stave off emergencies like acute asthma attacks, and better use of family doctors would help make emergency room business dwindle.

headline.main: Emergency Room, to Many, Remains the Doctor's Office

docs.abstract: Emergency room visits are rising despite managed care goal of using better preventive care and better access to family doctors to reduce such visits; factors include lack of access to primary care doctors among poorest Americans, large number of Americans without insurance and convenience of emergency rooms; Commonwealth Fund study finds three out of four visits to New York City emergency rooms are for nonemergencies; health care experts hold too few doctors enter primary care field or are willing to work late hours or weekends because of low insurance reimbursements; doctors say emergency rooms are being crushed under load in many areas of nation, especially in cities with large numbers of uninsured; hospitals in regions where they compete for business, like NYC, are learning to accept and even welcome increased load, making emergency rooms feel like private doctor's office; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: No one goes to work in a clothes-hanger factory to have fun or make a lot of money. The 275-odd employees of the plant that Tyco International acquired here in 1996 earn $5.75 to $9.55 an hour to churn out plastic hangers. In each 8-hour shift, just two 15-minute rest periods, plus a 5-minute ''water break'' are allowed. No lunch. Every other week, they are required to work an extra Saturday. ''The reason people came here was the benefits were good,'' said Jody Geist, a 13-year veteran who makes $8.93 an hour. ''The work was bad. The money wasn't good. But we have a good health insurance plan. And now, that's what they want to take away.''

headline.main: Factory Workers Fight the Squeeze On Health Benefits

docs.abstract: Tyco International is leaning on workers at its A&E Products plant in Ringtown, Pa, to give up traditional indemnity health insurance plan and approve managed care plan that Tyco says could save A&E Products $500,000 a year; across country, nine out of 10 Americans who receive health coverage at work are now enrolled in some form of managed care, and proportion with indemnity plans has fallen by more than half; company has told workers that they must either accept managed care or undergo mass layoffs; graph; chart; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE 20 doctors in the Katonah Medical Group in northern Westchester County are not anti-technology. Some even describe themselves as techies, eager to try new gadgets and regularly surfing the Internet. They know that the Internet is the future, that it will ultimately improve the speed and accuracy of what they do, from billing insurance companies to prescribing drugs.

headline.main: HEALTH: Hospital, Clinic, Practice: 3 Views of Doctors and the Web; Privacy, Costs and Wariness Slow One Medical Group's Web Use

docs.abstract: Twenty doctors in Katonah Medical Group in northern Westchester County find that privacy, cost and wariness of relying on technology dampen their eagerness to utilize Web services more extensively; photo (M)
docs.snippet: THE 20 doctors in the Katonah Medical Group in northern Westchester County are not anti-technology. Some even describe themselves as techies, eager to try new gadgets and regularly surfing the Internet.     They know that the Internet is the future,...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE nation's health insurance companies are rushing, belatedly in most cases, to transfer their exasperating, clunky dealings with doctors and patients to the Internet. After 10 years of trying to save money by spending less on care, they hope to squeeze savings from their bloated administrative costs. The companies also hope that by delivering information to patients and doctors in real time over the Internet, they will ease some of the frustration with denials of care and months of delays in payments that have stoked public anger against managed care. And the insurers think they can greatly increase their productivity by reducing misunderstandings online and promptly answering questions from doctors and patients about whether a particular treatment is covered.

headline.main: After Managed Care, Insurers Look to the Web for Plan B

docs.abstract: Health insurance companies rush to transfer their data to formats retrievable instantly over Internet; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 50 lawsuits against health maintenance organizations will be heard by a federal judge in Florida, a judicial panel said on Monday. The ruling is an early procedural victory for the plaintiffs, whose arguments to transfer the cases to Judge Federico Moreno of Federal District Court in Miami were accepted by the multidistrict litigation panel.

headline.main: Panel Sends 50 H.M.O. Suits to One Judge

docs.abstract: More than 50 lawsuits against health maintenance organizations will be heard by Judge Federico Moreno in Florida; ruling is early procedural victory for plaintiffs, whose arguments to transfer cases to Moreno were accepted by multidistrict litigation panel; lawsuits contend that HMO's violated federal law by breaching their duty to protect patients' health; seven HMO's, including Aetna and Cigna Corp, have been named in lawsuits on behalf of tens of millions of subscribers and 80 percent of nation's physicians (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: BACK when the idea of e-health seemed fresh and inevitably lucrative, three companies were often described as the sector's sure winners: Medscape, Healtheon and WebMD. In a new and already crowded field, the three promised to go beyond the popular patient information sites and change the nature of medical communication, restructure the nation's health care systems and, oh yes, save lives. Investors in 1999 reacted with Pavlovian shouts of ''buy'' for these and many other health-related dot-com stock offerings. But doctors and consumers yawned, and Wall Street quickly pulled the rug out, just as it had done with so many other Internet companies. So the question is: What will they do now?

headline.main: No Fun for Sisyphus: the Woes of WebMd and Medscape

docs.abstract: Medscape, WebMD and other Internet sites disseminate medical information; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Kaiser Permanente tries to persuade members to join its online service, the health care giant likes to talk about its advice-nurse feature, which guarantees a response to questions within 24 hours. It is a popular part of the service. So when the system broke down and e-mail messages from members started to pile up last summer, Kaiser technicians worked to solve the problem, and fast.

headline.main: If a Site Is All About Your Health, Who Else Might Be Peeking?

docs.abstract: Kaiser Permanente, health-maintenance organization, encourages use of Internet for uses as varied as scheduling appointments, renewing prescriptions, obtaining personal advice and storing patients' medical histories; chief concern: privacy of personal information; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton is missing an opportunity to promote breast and cervical cancer awareness, Representative Rick A. Lazio said today, by deciding to privately sign a bill that Mr. Lazio had backed. Speaking to reporters here before touring a breast cancer screening center at a hospital, Mr. Lazio said he believed politics might have influenced the White House's decision not to hold a public bill-signing ceremony.

headline.main: Lazio Criticizes President on Cancer Bill

docs.abstract: Repr Rick Lazio charges that President Clinton is missing opportunity to promote breast and cervical cancer awareness by deciding to privately sign bill that Lazio had backed; says he believes politics might have influenced White House's decision not to hold public bill-signing ceremony; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore is in excellent health and has not taken a sick day in eight years in the White House, Mr. Gore and his doctor said in their first full interviews about Mr. Gore's health. Mr. Gore is ''fit for duty,'' Dr. Richard J. Tubb, a White House physician and Mr. Gore's personal doctor since mid-1995, said of his patient on a flight on Air Force Two from Milwaukee to Washington on Oct. 11. The Democratic presidential nominee has put off a physical exam. ''I have been begging Dr. Tubb to schedule it,'' he said drily. Speaking of checkups, Mr. Gore went on: ''I love them! Doesn't everybody?''
docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore and his doctor, Richard J Tubb, in their first full interviews about his health, say Gore is in excellent health and has not taken sick day in eight years as Vice President; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A common theme is emerging on newspaper opinion pages as they begin issuing their endorsements for the Senate race in New Jersey. Those that favor the Democratic candidate, Jon S. Corzine, do so in spite of what they call his campaign spending excesses. Those who favor the Republican, Representative Bob Franks, do so largely because of Mr. Corzine's spending. The New York Times editorial board endorsed Mr. Franks while acknowledging that ''if political philosophy were the only consideration, we would be for Mr. Corzine.'' [Editorial, Page A26.]

headline.main: Corzine's Spending Leaps Off the Page

docs.abstract: Common theme is emerging on newspaper opinion pages as they begin issuing their endorsements for Senate race in New Jersey; those that favor Democratic candidate, Jon S Corzine, do so in spite of what they call his campaign spending excesses; those who favor Repr Robert D Franks, Republican, do so largely because of Corzine's spending (M)
